string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: image: https://www.flickr.com/photos/197763484@n02/52709971543/in/photolist-n97z2k-yqd4nu-k6twpw-2gvicb8-2gvizpg-2mnjon1-2gvhy5j-2gvhwg3-2max4z9-2o2dgca-xdyse3-xxuqgc-o31hya-939spd-dvwu1p-gzsy7h-2nsqzcs-2nqnys2-2nspx3s-g99qjs-2hzicvn-88u1wr-6uuk1m-883fep-6lsmgx-nn5rxg-hys9r-mm2zqg-zdvwhw-234mjvp-2iqts9v-2n8trsd-2njwvp7-2mpkdii-2mjgjse-2oino9p-2ojryc2-2ookmpk-2ouk936-rh2ggh-omk8hd-oplldk-bbzqxt-2k57eyx-zgxapg-huwvbh-2ok2dcc-2mpso3q-vv4f9q-2ok2ad6 keeping kiddos interested! presented by: lisabeth jones
introduction
welcome to the course todays course was developed to be interactive and thought provoking. you will be ushered by a guide, answer questions, and stay engaged.
the problem research tells us that students are bored in school about a third to half of the time they are there.
the problem continues kids can also lack motivation because they have trouble with academic skills that could be caused by several different things.
todays big idea we will look at the problem of keeping k-12 students engaged when using online learning & explore interactive technology to promote engagement.
meet your guide hi, i am laura. i will be your guide in todays course. you will see my friendly, familiar face throughout the presentation.

please enter your name before clicking the next button no yes does your name look correct? whats your name? please take a moment to tell me your name so we can have a personalized and interactive experience. %name% type your first name here

youre the judge %name%! question: how knowledgeable are you with different learning technology and available resources? directions: turn the dial to rate your level of knowledge. (0 = i mostly use textbooks & paper, 12 = i can teach learning technology courses) directions: turn the dial to rate your level of knowledge. (0 = i mostly use textbooks & paper, 12 = i can teach learning technology courses) 6 0 12
trigger phase
benefits for students online learning provides various benefits for students, including independence, help within a few clicks or keystrokes, & immediate feedback.
benefits for teachers there are so many positives to utilizing online learning. dont think its just a way to get out of in-person or synchronous lectures.

assessment survey question directions: click on the radio button below the emoji that applies to you, and explain why you chose that answer. r super motivated! pretty motivated kinda motivated that sounds like a lot of work survey prompt: i am motivated to find ways to get my students excited about learning. explain answer here:
assessment survey debrief there is no right or wrong answer to the survey question, but keep in mind that we cant expect our students to be motivated if we arent motivated.
humor helps a study found that students did better and scored higher on assessments when their instructor incorporated humor into their lectures.
better learning & health neurologist, judy willis, found that when people have fun interactions their levels of dopamine, endorphins, and oxygen increase.

assessment survey question directions: click on the box below the answer that applies to you, %name%, and explain why you chose that answer. survey prompt: i feel i have the ability to connect with my students using humor and having fun. explain answer here:
assessment survey debrief again, there is no right or wrong answer to the survey question. we each have strengths and weakness, humor may or may not be yours.
learning objectives:after this course, participants will be able to:
exploration phase
define the concern why do you think your students arent interested or engaged? the first step is to find out what is going on & why they arent connecting with the course.
skill deficit when a child experiences continued academic struggles, they can become embarrassed or irritated & give up.
social factors shame & humiliation can cause a child to withdraw, self-isolate, & may impact their academic performance.
are they bored? students who are bored in class might find the topic dull, the lesson may not be presented in an intriguing way, or the student may not feel challenged.

assessment time! when finding out why students arent engaged at school, we first need to find out what is happening. %name%, what are some reasons why a child might be bored or disinterested in school? note: type your response in the text box type your response here:

the answers are what are some reasons why a child might be bored or disinterested in school? there could be many answers to this question. some of the reasons we have already discussed are: academic struggles personal problems (at home or school) mental health issues (ex. depression, anxiety, adhd, ocd) learning disorders (ex. dyslexia) behind peers in academic knowledge/ability social factors bullied isolated uncomfortable or embarrassed around others bored not being intellectually challenged doesnt understand why they need to know something doesnt like the way information is presented keep in mind, these arent the only possibilities a child might be bored or disinterested in school.
assessment survey debrief there could be many reasons why a child isnt engaged in class, to include skills deficits, social factors, or outright boredom.
make lessons interesting the one thing we can control is how we create & deliver our lessons. it takes time, but the outcome for our students pays dividends.
include videos including videos in your course will introduce variety into your lessons & build background knowledge for topics.
interactive technology interactive technology can be as simple as adding clickable quizzes to a lesson or as advanced as introducing augmented reality (ar) in the classroom.
add voiceover consider adding voiceover to your slide presentations to eliminate text heavy slides & allow students to use multiple senses to receive the info.
learning community an online learning community will infuse social learning in the mix. this gives learners a place to talk about content & help each other.

helps students want to learn helps students want to learn helps students want to learn helps students want to learn helps students want to learn helps students want to learn helps students become interested in learning helps students become interested in learning helps students become interested in learning helps students become interested in learning helps students become interested in learning helps students become interested in learning makes students less interested in school makes students less interested in school makes students less interested in school makes students less interested in school makes students less interested in school makes students less interested in school helps students socialize with online groups helps students socialize with online groups helps students socialize with online groups helps students socialize with online groups helps students socialize with online groups helps students socialize with online groups will make children teach themselves will make children teach themselves will make children teach themselves will make children teach themselves will make children teach themselves will make children teach themselves allow students to work at own pace allow students to work at own pace allow students to work at own pace allow students to work at own pace allow students to work at own pace allow students to work at own pace can stimulate curiosity can stimulate curiosity can stimulate curiosity can stimulate curiosity can stimulate curiosity can stimulate curiosity %name%, what are reasons why its important to make online courses interactive & engaging? assessment time!

the answers are what are reasons why its important to make online courses interactive & engaging? -helps students want to learn -helps students become interested in learning -helps students socialize with online groups -allows students to work at own pace -can stimulate curiosity

assessment survey question directions: click on the answer that applies to you and explain why you chose that answer. question: i feel i can utilize technology to develop interactive online lessons explain answer here:
assessment survey debrief again, there is no right or wrong answer to the survey question. this depends heavily on your comfort with technology & the time you have available.
reminder: humor helps not everyone has a knack for humor, but there are ways to incorporate humor & fun into courses without having to be a comedian.
integration phase
case study %name%, in this section you will use the information from this course to work through a case study. ill be here with you to help you through the case study.
introduction: mr. hernandez hi, im anthony hernandez. i teach 7th grade math in a public school. i have been teaching for 7 years, and we just started the second semester.
initial information today i noticed that james, one of my best students, was a bit withdrawn. he is typically active & vocal in class.
introduction: james hi, im james. im a 7th grade student. i usually get as & bs on my report card. i like most of my teachers, and i feel like i can talk to them.

introduction: sarah/mrs. thomas hi, im sarah, or mrs. thomas to my students. i teach social studies at the same school that my son, james attends. our family is very close & we like doing things together.

whats happening now its been a few days, and james continues to act like he is checked out. im getting concerned. %name%, what do you think i should do? select one of these options to proceed with the case study. option 1: hes a teenager, im sure its just a phase. let it go. option 2: keep an eye on james and if hes still like this in a week or so, talk to his mom since she works here too. option 3: ask him to come see me today during flex period so i can talk to him.

scenario 1, option #1 hes a teenager. im sure its just a phase. let it go unless he starts becoming a distraction in class. %name%, is this the option you want to go with? yes no is this the option you want, %name%? if so, click on yes. if you would like to make a different option, click on no.

scenario 1, option #3 ask james to come see me today during flex period, so the two of us can talk & try to find out whats going on. %name%, is this the option you want to go with? yes no is this the option you want, %name%? if so, click on yes. if you would like to make a different option, click on no.

scenario 1, option #2 keep an eye on james, and if hes still like this in a week or so, talk to his mom since her classroom is in the next hallway. %name%, is this the option you want to go with? is this the option you want, %name%? if so, click on yes. if you would like to make a different option, click on no. yes no

reaction: scenario 1, option #1 james continues to be withdrawn in class & he hasnt turned in his homework in two days. %name%, what do you think mr. hernandez should do (scenario 2)? decide what mr. hernandez should do, and click on one of these options to continue with the case study. option 1: go have a talk with james mom during lunch. option 2: mr. hernandez should ask james to come see him today during flex period so he can speak with him.
reaction: scenario 1, option #2 mrs. thomas is receptive to mr. hernandezs concerns, but she is frustrated that he waited this long to address the problem.
reaction: scenario 1, option #3 mr. hernandez tells james that he is concerned because he hasnt been involved in class like he usually is. he asks james if something is wrong.

scenario 2, option #1 im going to go talk to james mom during lunch. %name%, is this the option you want to go with? no yes is this the option you want, %name%? if so, click on yes. if you would like to make a different option, click on no.

scenario 2, option #2 mr. hernandez is going to ask james to come see him during flex period today so they can talk. %name%, is this the option you want to go with? yes no is this the option you want, %name%? if so, click on yes. if you would like to make a different option, click on no.
reaction: scenario 2, option #1 mrs. thomas is receptive to mr. hernandezs concerns. she asks if he has spoken to james to see what he says about the situation.
reaction: scenario 2, option #2 mr. hernandez tells james that he is concerned because he hasnt been involved in class & is missing assignments. he asks james if something is wrong.
case study conclusion james & mrs. thomas meet with mr. hernandez to discuss the situation together. they discuss options on how the class can be more stimulating for james.
case study debrief james started showing disinterest in class & his teacher needed to find out why. after discussing it with him, he discovered that james was bored because the content was too easy.
resolution phase
crossing finish line to wrap-up, there is a summative evaluation that will encompass information from this course.
final evaluation instructions the exam will take 5-15 minutes to complete, & it consists of 5 questions. you must get at least 80% to pass.
when students are bored in class it is only because they are lazy. true true true true true true false false false false false false question 1 question type: true or false
typically, when a child experiences ongoing academic problems, they can get embarrassed or irritated & try harder give up seek help make friends question 2 question type: word bank/drag & drop

a. a bored child a. a bored child a. a bored child a. a bored child a. a bored child a. a bored child b. skill deficit b. skill deficit b. skill deficit b. skill deficit b. skill deficit b. skill deficit c. social factors c. social factors c. social factors c. social factors c. social factors c. social factors d. lack of humor d. lack of humor d. lack of humor d. lack of humor d. lack of humor d. lack of humor shame & humiliation can cause a child to withdraw, self-isolate, & may impact their academic performance. this statement is an example of what? question 3 question type: multiple choice

to combat boredom due to course content, educators need to make lessons . the one thing teachers can control is how lessons are created & delivered. type your text here question 4 question type: fill-in-the-blank

utilize learning communities utilize learning communities utilize learning communities utilize learning communities utilize learning communities utilize learning communities interactive technology interactive technology interactive technology interactive technology interactive technology interactive technology use videos use videos use videos use videos use videos use videos d. add audio/voiceover to slide shows d. add audio/voiceover to slide shows d. add audio/voiceover to slide shows d. add audio/voiceover to slide shows d. add audio/voiceover to slide shows d. add audio/voiceover to slide shows select strategies to help combat boredom & engage students in the classroom. question 5 question type: multiple selection (select all that apply)
course certificate congratulations, %name% you successfully completed the course! %name%

final message thank you for joining me & for your commitment to your students. be sure to check out the next slide for great resource links. if you have any questions or want to reach out to me for more information, i can be contacted via email at jones.1553@wright.edu

conclusion resource slide h5p: students can create quizzes, games & other learning tools. https://h5p.org merge cube: students can explore the water cycle, view fossils, examine rocks, experiment with machines, and more. https://mergeedu.com/ cospaces edu: students can explore ar & create their own experiences in any subject area. https://cospaces.io/edu/ assemblr: students can create content as well as explore already created content. ex. ocean animals, planets, symmetry, fractions, or how to do exercises https://edu.assemblrworld.com/assemblr-edu-app augmented classroom: lets students learn about plants, animals & explore the world. https://augmented-classroom.com/ thinkific creator community: for online course creators to share tips & advice. https://support.thinkific.com/hc/en-us/articles/360030353434-the-thinkific-creator-community 7 steps to building a online community (with examples) https://www.thinkific.com/blog/how-to-build-an-online-community/?utm_source=partnerstack&utm_medium

references: alber, r. (2019, march 18). using video content to amplify learning. edutopia. https://www.edutopia.org/article/using-video-content-amplify-learning/ brain science, engagement. (2023, march 14). why fun in learning works better than dull learning. growth engineering. https://www.growthengineering.co.uk/why-fun-in-learning-is-important/ burton, c. (2022, january 6). how to make online learning more engaging. elearning industry. https://elearningindustry.com/how-to-make-online-learning-more-engaging cohen, d. (2023, april 27). does your child lack motivation? child mind institute. https://childmind.org/article/does-your-child-lack-motivation/#:~:text=one%20of%20the%20most%20common,%2c%20anxiety%2c%20depression%20or%20ocd. cornwall, g. (2022, september 28). why your child might be bored at school and what to do about it. u.s. news & world report. https://www.usnews.com/education/k12/articles/why-your-child-might-be-bored-at-school-and-what-to-do-about-it#:~:text=research%20suggests%20that%20students%20are,on%20school%20because%20of%20boredom. the benefits of online education in a virtual classroom. (n.d.). drexel university school of education. retrieved july 1, 2023, from https://drexel.edu/soe/resources/student-teaching/advice/benefits-of-online-and-virtual-learning/ washington office of superintendent of public instruction. (2020, march 16). keeping students learning tips for online and offline learning. oer commons. https://oercommons.org/courseware/lesson/64064/overview

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: 7 Steps To Building A Online Community (With Examples)

terms.term: Common neurodevelopmental disorder usually diagnosed in childhood that often lasts into adulthood. Children may have trouble paying attention, controlling impulsive behaviors, or be overly active.
feeling of fear, dread, and uneasiness.
common medical illness that negatively affects how you feel, the way you think, and how you act.
A chemical released in the brain that makes you feel happy, excited, & stimulated. Having the right amount is important for your brain and body.

a learning disorder/disability that involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how to relate to letters and words (decoding). Dyslexia is a result of individual differences in areas of the brain that process language.
the happiness hormones that are linked with feeling enchantment.
behavioral symptom that disrupts a person's ability to manage their own thoughts, emotions and actions.
a common, chronic, and long-lasting diorder where a person has uncontrollable, recurring thoughts (obsessions) and /or behaviors (compulsions) that they feel the urge to repeat over and over.
Synchronous classes are in real time with students and instructors attending together from different locations.
